body_html:
OK! I fresh installed OSX 10.13, used current Xcode and command line tools 8.2, cuda 9.1 and cudnn 7.0.5. The package built! But I'm still getting torch.cuda.is_available() --> False. Any ideas?
…
On Tue, May 22, 2018 at 7:36 AM, Hugh Runyan ***@***.***> wrote: I was using command line tools and xcode 8.2. I tried the former command line tools with xcode 9.3.1 as well? But I believe you are correct that the problem is somewhere in the gcc universe. The card isn't external -- I have geforce 750M GT onboard. It's not fast by modern GPU standards, but should be a lot faster than CPU. It has nvidia compute power (or whatever exactly they call it) 3.0. On Tue, May 22, 2018 at 6:20 AM, Hongbin Liu ***@***.***> wrote: > Cuda9.1 + cudnn 7 + 10.13.4 + egpu works for me, gotta make sure the gcc > version and the command are correct though. > > — > You are receiving this because you were mentioned. > Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub > <#7721 (comment)>, > or mute the thread > <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/APJZbevy1C29vosMMra6KLZ670oCsv1pks5t1BC0gaJpZM4UGVB0> > . >
body_text:
OK! I fresh installed OSX 10.13, used current Xcode and command line tools
8.2, cuda 9.1 and cudnn 7.0.5. The package built! But I'm still
getting torch.cuda.is_available() --> False. Any ideas?
…
On Tue, May 22, 2018 at 7:36 AM, Hugh Runyan ***@***.***> wrote:
 I was using command line tools and xcode 8.2. I tried the former command
 line tools with xcode 9.3.1 as well? But I believe you are correct that the
 problem is somewhere in the gcc universe. The card isn't external -- I have
 geforce 750M GT onboard. It's not fast by modern GPU standards, but should
 be a lot faster than CPU. It has nvidia compute power (or whatever exactly
 they call it) 3.0.

 On Tue, May 22, 2018 at 6:20 AM, Hongbin Liu ***@***.***>
 wrote:

> Cuda9.1 + cudnn 7 + 10.13.4 + egpu works for me, gotta make sure the gcc
> version and the command are correct though.
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <#7721 (comment)>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/APJZbevy1C29vosMMra6KLZ670oCsv1pks5t1BC0gaJpZM4UGVB0>
> .
>
body:
OK! I fresh installed OSX 10.13, used current Xcode and command line tools
8.2, cuda 9.1 and cudnn 7.0.5. The package built! But I'm still
getting torch.cuda.is_available() --> False. Any ideas?

On Tue, May 22, 2018 at 7:36 AM, Hugh Runyan <hurunyan@ucsd.edu> wrote:

> I was using command line tools and xcode 8.2. I tried the former command
> line tools with xcode 9.3.1 as well? But I believe you are correct that the
> problem is somewhere in the gcc universe. The card isn't external -- I have
> geforce 750M GT onboard. It's not fast by modern GPU standards, but should
> be a lot faster than CPU. It has nvidia compute power (or whatever exactly
> they call it) 3.0.
>
> On Tue, May 22, 2018 at 6:20 AM, Hongbin Liu <notifications@github.com>
> wrote:
>
>> Cuda9.1 + cudnn 7 + 10.13.4 + egpu works for me, gotta make sure the gcc
>> version and the command are correct though.
>>
>> —
>> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
>> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
>> <https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/issues/7721#issuecomment-390987042>,
>> or mute the thread
>> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/APJZbevy1C29vosMMra6KLZ670oCsv1pks5t1BC0gaJpZM4UGVB0>
>> .
>>
>
>
